Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Improving the Accessibility and Trust of Voice-based Social Media for Small Farmers in Developing Regions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
World food security depends on improving the productivity and profitability of small farmers across the developing world. Unfortunately, many of these farmers do not benefit from the latest information and technologies. With the right access, these farmers could solve their own problem. Unfortunately, due to their often limited education and technological access, the text-based, English-dominated Internet is not a useful resource for most small farmers across the world. On the other hand, low-cost mobile phones and wireless connectivity are revolutionizing communications. This research seeks to understand how voice-based social media, deployed on mobile phones, can be used by agrarian communities for collaborative problem-solving, information access and knowledge generation. In particular, the investigators are interested in the following research questions. 1) How can we make voice-based user interfaces more intuitive and accessible for users with limited formal education? 2) How can we make voice-based information more trust-worthy for users with no prior experience assessing online information resources? 3) What is the economic impact of providing access to new sources of information and advice?

Answering these questions can improve the design and adoption of voice-based social media applications worldwide. Advances could also make information access more intuitive for other inexperienced users, such as the elderly. Making information and services more accessible to marginalized groups holds tremendous potential for benefiting society. By making more voices heard, governments and service organizations can better understand and address their needs. This research will be conducted in collaboration with local non-profit organizations and community groups in India, who are actively developing and deploying real, working voice applications. By designing and testing proof-of-concept applications, we can influence wider scaling through empirical demonstrations of usability, adoption and impact. This research provides opportunities for students to develop new sustainable enterprises and working products. By conducting fieldwork abroad, U.S.-based students will develop a broader understanding of the opportunities and challenges of working there. Such opportunities can attract diverse new students to Computer Science - including women and minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This  project seeks to design, implement and evaluate voice-based system in Gujarat, India, wherein small farmers use an interactive voice response (IVR) interface to ask and answer agricultural questions, and to receive relevant agricultural information. This proposal addresses the following research questions regarding voice-based social media for developing regions: 1. How will low-literacy users find needed information? 2. How will they assess the credibility of information? 3. What is the economic impact of new sources of information? Randomized, controlled experiments have found that: 1) Small farmers in Gujarat valued and acted upon information from their peers more often than information from experts. This surprising finding can inform the design of other knowledge dissemination efforts for small farmers, 2) Influential nodes in the social network could determine how to target information to recipients more effectively then simple data-driven approaches. This finding can allow us to develop more cost-effective and efficient mechanisms for delivering information in agricultural contexts in the developing world, and 3) Voice-based social media can have significant impact on farmer decision-making and adoption of beneficial farming practices. This finding can support poiicy makers and agricultural extension organizations who want to use this approach to improve their existing knowledge dissemination efforts. In addition to this work on agriculture, the project has also explored the applicability of  voice-based social media in other domains - including for education, health information dissemination and for improving financial literacy. Our results demonstrated the applicability of the approach in other domains, but that privacy is also a significant concern (in particular, for collecting and disseminating health-related information). We also began a new project to understand the impact and adoption of new smartphone-based services among poor, rural populations in India. In particular, we are studying the learning and usage of Internet search applications by novice computer users from marginalized communities with low english language and literacy skills. In terms of technology transfer, our open source software has been commercialized by a start-up company in India (started by a former student on the project) that is providing a hosted platform for voice-based services and content. This start-up is now supporting a number of other applications and uses of the technology. The system offered by this company currently has more then 100,000 users across India and several other countries.
